body_html:
note that a[:-1] doesn't extract whole of a, it stops one element short, and strided_slice copies numpy semantics

If you want to go all the way, you could do a[:] in Python subscript notation (which is syntactic sugar for strided_slice) or use end_mask argument to ignore the endpoint

y=tf.strided_slice(x, [0, 0, 0, 0], [-1, -1, -1, -1], [1, 2, 2, 1], end_mask=8)
body_text:
note that a[:-1] doesn't extract whole of a, it stops one element short, and  strided_slice copies numpy semantics
If you want to go all the way, you could do a[:] in Python subscript notation (which is syntactic sugar for strided_slice) or use end_mask argument to ignore the endpoint
y=tf.strided_slice(x, [0, 0, 0, 0], [-1, -1, -1, -1], [1, 2, 2, 1], end_mask=8)
body:
note that `a[:-1]` doesn't extract whole of `a`, it stops one element short, and  `strided_slice` copies numpy semantics

If you want to go all the way, you could do a[:] in Python subscript notation (which is syntactic sugar for `strided_slice`) or use `end_mask` argument to ignore the endpoint

`y=tf.strided_slice(x, [0, 0, 0, 0], [-1, -1, -1, -1], [1, 2, 2, 1], end_mask=8)`
